title: Thin film - blue AR coating of glass and plastic

content.description: Engineers are testing different antireflection films to minimize the reflection of blue light when a film coats either plastic or glass. They have two film materials, Material <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>X</mtext></math> of refractive index <math alttext="n sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></math> and Material <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Y</mtext></math> of refractive index <math alttext="n sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math>. The glass and plastic have refractive indexes of <math alttext="n sub G" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>G</mtext></msub></math> and <math alttext="n sub P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>P</mtext></msub></math>, respectively. Material <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>X</mtext></math> does not adhere to the plastic, so it is only tested with the glass. Material <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Y</mtext></math> is tested with both the plastic and the glass. For each test, the engineers use the minimum film thickness that results in the minimum amount of reflected blue light, as follows:
